title: Why is Bring Me Back to Life considered a Linkin Park song? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s not at all a Linkin Park song. Though, from what I remember from reading about it before, at the time when Evanescence was was recording Fallen, their label really wanted them to do something with Linkin Park. Why? Money. We all know that’d be like the absolute biggest thing at the time if that were to happen. Maybe not now, but back when they were starting to establish themselves. Problem: Amy Lee knew Mike & Chester wouldn’t really be into the idea. To them, it would’ve just looked like a move to sell more records, and if you know LP, you’d know that at this time they just wanted to put of most of their stuff on their own. Really they haven’t done much collaboration in the form of a feature, excluding Reanimation, like that until Recharged came out (and even that was another remix album, so “The Hunting Party” for those of you who wanna just follow the studio album chronology). Plus, Meteora, which some say was a “forced album” by the label, was about to come out. I doubt they’d have wanted to take any more pressure from Warner Brothers to do a collaboration with Evanescence at the time. Anyways, sorry if I’m rambling, but you wanna know why people mistakenly associate Bring Me To Life with Linkin Park?  Your good old Budget Mike Shinoda. This is actually Paul McCoy from the band “12 Stones”. Literally never heard of the guy before writing this answer, so I’m not gonna judge him or anything. Hell, I’ll check out 12 Stones write after I submit this. But yeah, people commonly mistake this guy’s parts (“wake me up!” , “all of this time, I can’t believe I couldn’t see” , etc) for Mike’s rapping. Some people say it sounded like Chester somehow. I don’t see it. Though, I haven’t listened to the song for a while. Anyways, that’s probably why people like to stick Linkin Park’s name in front of the song as a feature or the artist. Honestly, it could help if they bothered to add “Feat. Paul McCoy” when they released it for distribution. This guy probably would’ve gotten a lot more attention. And that’s about all I know on the matter. I’m sure I must be missing some details so if someone knows the whole story and wants me to edit this, I’ll be glad to do so.

I know, I faced this problem some 3 or 4 years back...and that's how I came across Evanescence, after Linkin Park. Look, I have no idea why on earth "Bring Me Back to Life" is tagged with LP, even on YouTube or most sites that support mp3 download. My theory is that perhaps initially there was a confusion, which led to a chain reaction. "Bring Me Back to Life" is clearly a song by Evanescence. Some do say that the beats of the song are like those of LP, but that clearly doesn't make any sense!  Such confusions have occurred with other bands and their songs as well, but right now, I can't think of another suitable example.
